--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> > >On Thu, 19 Aug 2004 22:05:44 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> 
wrote:
> > However, (wait
> > for it) I just had a quick look at the code and it /looks/ like 
it might
> > actually be taking excess and disjoint genes from *both* 
parents. 
> 
> Well, that might explain the bloat, but I still don't understand 
how
> the fitness at the end of both complexifying and blended runs is
> *worse* than the random initial population.
> 
> Ken wrote:
> > Therefore, it is possible in one domain that those that do
> > better tend to be simpler because of some property of the fitness
> > function (i.e. the domain) and therefore the complexity will go
> > down, whereas in a more difficult domain only more complex
> > individuals are able to improve fitness and therefore complexity
> > will go up.
> 
> I understand this principle, but this is not my main concern with
> Colin's preliminary results.
> 
> Have a look at this graph:
> 
> http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/phasedsearching/ocr-
complexifying.png
> 
> This is a traditional NEAT run in Colin's domain.  The max fitness 
for
> this domain is 260, I believe.  For the first few hundred 
generations,
> the population improves to about 80, but for the next several
> *thousand* generations, the max and average fitness for the 
population
> gets worse and worse, ending up essentially as good as the initial
> random population (~10).
> 
> This isn't about simpler or more complex individuals performing 
better
> or worse.  This is about the entire population getting *worse*
> throughout the run.  It certainly seems to me that this is not the 
way
> NEAT is supposed to work.
> 

That definitely is a bit odd.  Colin, what was the number of 
generations of stagnation before a species was cut?  It looks like 
species were dying off pretty quickly there is that's really the 
underlying explanation for the downward trend.

ken
